title: A Spirit of Reverence
sub_title: Recognizing the Sacred in the Ordinary
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy was the heart of our small town. He wasn't wealthy, powerful, or even particularly talented. But he possessed something far more valuable: a deep and abiding sense of reverence. Every Sunday, he sat in the front pew of the church, his eyes closed, his lips moving in silent prayer even before the service began. It wasn't just a habit; it was a genuine expression of awe and respect for the divine.

What struck me most was how Mr. Abernathy carried that reverence into every aspect of his life. He treated everyone – from the mayor to the street sweeper – with the same quiet dignity and respect. He tended his garden with a meticulous care that bordered on sacredness. He spoke of nature, of art, of even the smallest acts of kindness with a hushed reverence that made you pause and consider the deeper meaning of things.

One afternoon, while helping him weed his rose bushes, I asked him about it. "Mr. Abernathy," I said, "where does all this reverence come from?"

He smiled, his eyes crinkling at the corners. "It comes," he said, "from recognizing the sacredness in everything. From understanding that every breath is a gift, every person a miracle, every moment an opportunity to connect with something larger than ourselves." He pointed to a tiny ladybug crawling on a rose petal. "Even that little creature is a testament to the wonder of creation." He added, "Reverence isn't about being solemn or pious all the time. It's about living with an awareness of the divine presence in the ordinary."

Reverence is not simply a feeling; it is a way of seeing and being in the world. It is the recognition of something higher, something worthy of our utmost respect and awe. As summer begins to give way to the golden hues of autumn, let us cultivate a spirit of reverence, appreciating the beauty and holiness in all things.
image_description: A close-up of a weathered, gnarled tree with sunlight filtering through its leaves, creating a sense of peace and timelessness.
insights: Psalm 111:10 declares, 'The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom; all who follow his precepts have good understanding.' The 'fear of the Lord' is not about being afraid, but rather about having a profound reverence and respect for God's power and holiness. This reverence is the foundation of true wisdom and understanding. Hebrews 12:28-29 reinforces this, urging us to 'offer to God acceptable worship with reverence and awe, for our God is a consuming fire.' It is this understanding of God's awesome power that inspires genuine reverence.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I have rushed through life, failing to recognize the sacredness in the ordinary. Open my eyes to see Your presence in every person, every creature, and every moment. Fill my heart with reverence and awe, that I may live each day with a deeper appreciation for Your creation and Your boundless love. Help me to approach You with the respect and honor You are due. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life could you cultivate a greater sense of reverence? What small steps can you take today to recognize the sacredness in the ordinary? How can you express your reverence for God in your daily actions and interactions?
